note.name: Books
note.contents:
A list of the books I've read and would like to re-read.

Reading

Reading is still the most viable way to take in new information from diverse sources. It can be easily paused, rewinded, and played at whatever pace you'd like. It doesn't produce sound, expire, or become unavailable.

I want to read more. I should start with fiction, but sometimes I lose track of character names. I might want to start noting down minor details so that I'm less likely to become lost and disinterested.

To Read

  • Never Split the Difference

Recommendations from Chad Mazolla

  • Lincoln in the Bardo
  • On the Shortness Of Life
  • When Breath Becomes Air
  • Man's Search For Meaning

Recommendations from Ryan Holiday

  • A Calendar of Wisdom: Daily Thoughts To Nourish the Soul
  • The Laws of Human Nature
  • The Fall

children_notes.name: How To Make Sense Of Any Mess
children_notes.contents: How To Make Sense of Any Mess is an online book about information architecture. I haven't finished it yet.

children_notes.name: How To Travel Full Time
children_notes.contents: How To Travel Full Time by Colin Wright is a short book that has some practical advice for those who want to travel and see the world.

children_notes.name: Incerto
children_notes.contents:
Incerto is a series of books about uncertainty and human error written by Nassim Nicholas Taleb.

I've read, but probably not fully understood:

  • Fooled by Randomness
  • The Black Swan

The books are eye-opening, but the nature of the topic makes them sometimes hard to process.

children_notes.name: On The Shortness Of Life
children_notes.contents:
On the Shortness of Life by Seneca is an essay about the nature of time.

Quotes I like:

It is a small part of life we really live.

How late it is to begin to really live when life must end!

children_notes.name: Some Thoughts About Relationships
children_notes.contents: Some Thoughts About Relationships by Colin Wright is about establishing a foundation to enter relationships mindfully. The logical approaches he suggests counter the emotional instability inherent in relationships, and he recommends using rationality to approach a better version of love that has less potential for negative feelings and more potential for respect, communication and happiness.
